''Lessons From Ancient Heat Surge'' (Nov. 23) reported on findings that point to a rapid, cataclysmic increase in global temperature resulting from the vast discharge of methane from the seabed to the atmosphere some 55 million years ago.

Climate scientists speculate that the gradual warming of the sort we are seeing right now could lead to such a cascade. Just for the sake of discussion, let's grant that hypothesis. What lesson would such a contemporary heat surge carry?

My reading would be the following: The way of life that raised the global temperature was fatally maladaptive. Put another way, consumer capitalism was civicidal. Any similarly destructive chain of events resulting from global warming would carry the same message. As the season of merchandising mania descends on us, these questions seem ripe for the asking.
DR. ROBERT B. LEVIN Carmel, Calif.
